independent political entity
The adaptive capacities of vulnerable rural populations to the additional risks posed by climate change on agricultural production and food security in Mali are enhanced

Existence of tools available to Malian actors NGOs associations decisions makers research institutes and technical services to support climate change adaptation activities in agriculture and food security sectors

comment.narrative: Scarce and incomplete
Toolkits available for each of the 4 agoecological zone in Mali

The range of tools developed or adapted by the project range from climate proofing planning tools sowing guidelines and calendars technical agricultural forms weather forecasting to other helping tools for decision making such as Social and AgroEconomical Analysis AAES and Technical data sheets to support decision making

description.narrative: Percentage change in projected i food production and ii income generation in the pilot municipalities for available climate scenarios

comment.narrative: Baseline will be evaluated at project inception in the context of project output 11
Projected food production and income generation have increased in the pilot municipalities for available climate scenario

The increase of both food production and income generated with the use of the resilient variety introduced by the project has been significant throughout the life of the project During the 20142015 season and despite am unfavorable rainfall that affected agriculture works in the project area several demonstration plots still recorded satisfactory results The Nyètaa Women Cooperative of Sandare Diallara produced an average yield of 2350 Kgha with the new maize variety against the community average yield of 450kgha in Massantola the agroforestry plots eucalyptusgroundnuts reached the yield of 1392 kgha against a local yield of 400450 kgha
The Jorobana maize variety reached 2292 kgha against the local variety production of 450 kgha
In Cinzana the sorghum CSM63E variety introduced by the project has a yield oscillating between 600 and 1320 kgha against a traditional production of 520 kgha Similarly the sorghum variety Toroniou C1 registered a yield between 960 and 1800 kgha against a traditional local production of 550 to 600kgha
The fodder niebe plot of Cinzana Gare Women Association Benkadji II harvested 800 bundles of stalks for ox animal feeding oxen and donkeys provided by the project in 20132014 The Tiéba hybride maize varieties in MPessoba reached a yield oscillating between 2680 and 3600kgha against a local production of 850900 kgha The average yield of introduced sorghums Séguifa Tiandougou and CSM63E is in the range of 1970 kgha against a traditional local production of 900950kgha Groubnut 4710 pure cultivar registered an average yield of 1700 kgha as against a traditional local production of 600650 kgha

description.narrative: Number of national and international partner organizations to which lessons learned of the project have been directly presented

comment.narrative:
The following 12 organizationsstakeholders participate in the implementation of the Project Direction Nationale de lAgriculture DNA National Agriculture Direction Agence de lEnvironnement et du Développement Durable AEDD Environment and Sustainable Development Agency Institut dEconomie Rurale IER Rural Economy Institute Agence Mali Météo Mali Meteorological Agence Direction Nationale des Eaux et Forêts DNEF National Direction of Wild life and Game Direction Nationale des Productions et Industries Animales DNPIA National Direction of Animal Production and Industries NGO Mali Folck Center LDCFFAO Project Office de la Haute Vallée du Niger OHVN Niger High Valley Authority Centre National de Recherche Scientifique et Technologique CNRST National Centre for Scientific and Technological Research and as at that they equally share the lessons learned by the Project
Furthermore some of the project results have been shared with UNDPs climate change adaptation regional advisors at the international level

description.narrative: Number of vulnerable municipalities in which the lessons learned and best practices identified throughout the project have been disseminated

comment.narrative: Indicative150

At this stage promoting the uptake of good agricultural practices is in process throughout the six 6 communes of the Project Dispositions are on the way for the organization of regional capitalization workshops with the aim of diffusing in the other project target communes and the 166 vulnerable communes of Food Security Commissariat

description.narrative: Capacities to prevent and manage the impacts of climate change on agricultural production and food security are improved
Budgetresources allocated to national and local strategies for adaptation

comment.narrative: Lowinexistent
Budget must be sufficient to implement articulated strategies and plans

The project supported the development of local funding strategies through the identification of decentralized financial structures operating in the communes of Sandare Massantola MPessoba and Cinzana and to establish a partnership to finance resilient agriculture that benefit eligible target populations
The newly established Mali National Climate Funds operational since March 2014 is dedicated to finance national and local strategies on adaptation and has been mobilized by the project for funding resilient agriculture

description.narrative: Existence of knowledge and tools within technical structures supporting rural development regarding needed adaptation measures in order to manage climate risks at the local level

comment.narrative: Low
High

Key stakeholders in project sites are already using the following tools developed or adapted by the project Climate Proofing Early Warning System the CRIWAR Geographical Information System the sowing period guide with 80 of success in forecasting the booklet of rainfall records the technical data sheets of seasonal forecasts and the tool of AgroEconomical and Social Analysis AAES
In addition the project organized several awareness workshops targeting agriculture research and education institutions at regional local and communal levels to raise awareness of climate change and include climate change modules in training curricula Sikasso Region 10 Segou Region 11 Koulikoro Region 6 Kayes Region 6

description.narrative: Number of municipalities having integrated adaptation considerations within their local development plans

comment.narrative: Very lowinexistent
High

Four communal plans for social and economic development PDESCs have integrated climate change issues these are for the communes of Cinzana Sandare Massantola and MPessoba
Unfortunately the insecurity and political unrest in the north of Mali has impeded work in the communes of Mondoro and Taboye

description.narrative: Number of national level agriculture or food securityrelated laws codes policies and strategies having integrated climate change and adaptation concerns

comment.narrative: low
High

At least 7 national policy documents were reviewed for integration of climate change and adaptation concerns particularly the Master Plan for Rural Development SDDR the National Strategy for the Development of Irrigation SDI the Agricultural Development Policy PDA the Agricultural Orientation Law LOA the National Policy for livestock breeding PNDE the Pastoral Charter the National Strategy for the Development of Fishery and Aquaculture SNDPA the law N 95032 of March 20 1995 laying down the conditions of fishing and fish farming and bylaws the National Strategy for Food Security NSSA and the National Policy for Food Security PNSA
Suggested revisions were informed by the project analyses of laws codes policies and strategies concerning and Agriculture Food Security The main recommendations are summarized as follows
i Take into account environmental issues particularly Climate Change at the very inception of the operations cycle in the implementation of rural development activities
ii ensure that all the rural development Sub Sector Agriculture Animal husbandry Fishery Food Security programs are environmentally sound
iii Finally rural development policies strategies and programs should emphasize the following adaptation measures
1 Sensitization on Climate Change and natural resources management protection of the environment
2 promotion of cultivar rotation system integrating soils management to meet the needs for water and sustainability
3 establishment of an early warning system
4 intensification of tree planting to benefit soil regeneration and a carbon sink
5 erosion control measures
6 promotion of equitable share of land so that land conservation measures should not misleadingly be considered as land dispossession
7 Drainage practices

description.narrative: Climate resilience of agricultural production systems and the most vulnerable agropastoral communities strengthened
Number of resilient agropastoral technologies or techniques demonstrated at the local level upon project closure

comment.narrative: Indicative 15

In addition to the resilient agro sylvo pastoral the following 6 practices and technologies have been applied
i the use of seeds of adapted cereals legumes fodder cultures and market garden varieties
ii agroforestry and tree planting
iii water resources mobilization has been effective through the realization of waterpoints and dams
iv organic manure production and usage technique has been demonstrated in the communes of Sandare Massantola Cinzana and MPessoba and applied by all the 160 producers ie 40 producers per commune The compost produce is in use in some demonstration plots
v Sowing Guide and Seasonal Forecast 2015
vi Broadcasting agro meteorological information through the rural radio services contributes to reinforcing the producers resilience to climate change

description.narrative: Number of resilient alternative livelihood strategies demonstrated at the local level upon project closure

comment.narrative: Indicative 15

The project promoted alternative livelihood strategies the most important being the development of vegetable garden to support women resilience To increase the number of beneficiaries and foster sustainability process for involving microfinance institutions have been undertaken 13 women associations and cooperatives with 999 members living in four communes received some equipment including plows carts and animals
In addition the project supported multifunctional platforms using solar system energy Recently the project also introduced bovine fattening units poultry farming as well as crafting activities for women dyeing pomade and soap manufacturing and tailoring as well as the production and sale of forest plants seedlings

description.narrative: Percentage increase in production on parcels testing the resilient technologies or techniques

comment.narrative: To be determined based on the type of production

Yields and productivity has increased significantly in the project areas and parcels As examples the Sandare Diallara Women Nyètaa Cooperative has achieved an average yield of 2350Kgha for maize as against a local traditional production yield of 450kgha corresponding to grow rate of 422
The Massantola eucalyptusgroundnut agroforestry plots reached a yield of1392 kgha as against a local traditional production yields of 400450 kgha amounting to a grow rate of 322753
Jorobana maize variety produced a yield of 2292 kgha as against a local traditional production yields of 450 kgha reaching a grow rate of 40933
In addition in pure cultivation the same corn variety recorded a yield fluctuating between 1430 kg to 3300kgha in the same locality
In Cinzana Sorghum CSM63E variety yields are oscillating between 600kg and 1320 kgha as against a local traditional production yields of 520 kgh ie a grow rate of 8462
Toroniou C1 Sorghum variety yields are oscillating between 960 et 1800 kgha as against local traditional production yields of 550 à 600kgha The grow rate is 151
The fodder Niebe plot of Cinzana Gare Benkadji II Women Association recorded 800 bundles of stalks for foxen animal feeding bulls and donkeys supplied by the Project in 20132014

description.narrative: Percentage of targeted farmers and local technical staff trained for collecting agrometeorological data and using agrometeorological information

comment.narrative: gt50

More than 70 of the technical staffs agents of agriculture livestock breeding water and forestry resources conservation NGOs and educational institutions involved in project activities in target communes trained on agrometeorological data collection and the use of agrometeorological information
A total of 200 farmers including 7 women and 8 technical agents have been trainedre trained on agrometeorological data collection One hundred and sixty 160 villages have been supplied with local rain gauges and rainfall data collection booklets
The above data concern the communes of Sandare Massantola Cinzana and MPessoba

Objective Expand the coverage of Malis protected estate and strengthen the management effectiveness of the protected area system focusing in the Southwest region and piloting new management models based on international PA categories
1 Increase in land area of national territory managed as a Protected Area

comment.narrative:
In 2010 baseline situation Mali counted on the following with respect to its PA estate and key areas in the South West part of the country
1a The countrys PA estate covers 5589476 hectares of gazetted protected areas covering 45 of Malis land area
1b Key habitats in the BafingFaleme region remain unprotected or were only recently gazetted
1c There is a project to create the BafingFaleme Biosphere Reserve as the first Transboundary Biosphere Reserve in Mali composed of a mosaic of PAs of different categories and under varied management regimes but only timid steps have been taken in this effectively creating the reserve
1d Within the central subcomplex of what will potentially be the Malian side of the BafingFaleme Transboundary Biosphere Reserve there are at least 250000 ha of paper parks or areas that are gazetted by law but not managed These include
i Wongo National Park 53599 ha
ii Kouroufing National Park 55770ha
iii Chimpanzee Sanctuary 67200 ha
iv Falawa Game Hunting Preserves ZIC 73940 ha
indicator adjusted through a more detailed explanation NOTE on LOGFRAME 2014 the text has been broken up in three numbered subindicators for the sake of readability no change to content made
Note from 1a Malis total territory covers 12 million sq km or more precisely 124113800 ha

By project end there will be major progress in expanding and operationalising Malis PA estate
1a The countrys PA estate reaches approximately 6270000 ha of gazetted PAs covering at least 5 of Mali land area This expansion will generally add 700000 ha of new protected areas to the estate of which i some 100000 ha are expected to be created within the target zone of the project and ii some 600000 ha would be from the establishment of the Tamesna Faunal Reserve for Gazelles in the TinEssakoKidal Region and for which the project is not responsible but may function as a catalyst eg through Output 12 on the PA Strategy
1b The zoning of the BafingFaleme Biosphere Reserve has been completed and a master plan for managing the Reserve as mosaic of protected areas of different categories and under varied management regimes provides protection to key habitats in the BafingFaleme region
1c The BafingFaleme Transboundary Biosphere Reserve has been created ie the legal dossiers for submission to UNESCO have been cleared at the countrys level in close coordination with the Government of Guinea and the documentation submitted to UNESCOs Assembly for approval
1d Former 250000 ha paper parks in the central subcomplex of the BafingFaleme Transboundary Biosphere plus some 100000 ha of new PAs within the mentioned reserve are under improved management this is evidenced by METT scores of 30 or above for the mentioned areas indicator adjusted through a more detailed explanation
NOTE on LOGFRAME 2014 the text has been broken up in three numbered subindicators for the sake of readability no change to content made
Note from 1a Output 12 reads National PA Strategy under preparation considers among other relevant factors the role of the new PA Authority sustainable financing options longterm PA expansion and consolidation potential climate change impacts on the PA system and defines immediate site action interventions for highly threatened PAs or endangered species dependent on a series of PAs

Making progress towards the target but given the implementation time left and the complexity of the tasks the target of PA expansion and strengthening is not likely to be achieved
After independent scrutiny by the MTR the following was concluded on this indicator
1a Only A PA of 32657 ha was created as a result of the project Order of the 9 May 2011 namely the Hunting area of Faragama Thus only 33 of the target of 100000 ha new PAs within the project zone was achieved Given local conflict in the area a forest management plan FMP has not been completed In addition activities in Community Reserves totalling 167699 ha are only at the first steps of implementation No community reserve CR was formally created with the assistance of the project In fact the legal process of CR creation has not even begun A precondition to it would be the adoption of the Law on Wildlife and its Habitat which is still in draft It will only be submitted for approval in September 2015 with expected adoption by December 2015 if the process is not made contentious Then the PA proclamation decrees would need to be submitted At best the proclamation of these community reserves would only be expected by June 2016 and therefore too late for the project to have an influence on it
1b The project has supported the management of 6 existing PA for a total 344149 ha These are i Kouroufing NP with 55770 ha ii Wongo NP with 53499 ha iii Bafing Chimpanzees Sanctuary with 67200 ha iv Flawa Hunting Preserve 739440 ha v Manda Wula Wildlife Reserve 39050 ha vi Mene and related Wildlife Reserve and its buffer and transition zone BTZ with 54690 ha PA strengthening activities have taken place but are still limited due to the lack of cofunding The management plans for Neme Wula and Mande Wula have not yet been approved by a MEADD order
1c The crossborder biosphere reserve is not created The MTR assessed that it wont be by the end of the project
Overall the MTR assessed that the MTR estimates tan the objective of this indicator is unlikely to be reached by the end and that if new PAs are still created these will be paper parks with no management on the ground Therefore the MTR suggested that the project should focus on the five CR with a total of 69912 ha
The projects replica is
Progress is being made to reach the target of creating new areas The estimates are around 167699 ha of new community areas to have created that have been delineated by boundary To achieve the objective the project has to go to the other steps of the classification process constitution of the classification committee publication of the limits of the new areas pending claims of riparian communities analysis of claims classification report and preparation of the act of filing its adoption and publication in the Official Journal The creation of the new board of management of protected areas is underway
Overall performance for this indicator was deemed as MU by the MTR

8b Staff has been recruited and is in place on the Wongo complex Even though they dont reach a sufficient number its a significant progress regarding the initial situation before the project They have been equipped with motorbikes Infrastructures have been restored a forest post in Niarakira has been restored and one is being constructed in Kouroukoto

description.narrative: 9 Alternative Livelihoods generate increased revenues for local populations

comment.narrative: No ecotourism economic activities in region
3 new community based ecotourism operations generating revenue and jobs

Target not achieved No ecotourism activity
A directory of cultural sites is outstanding preparation If people were well involved in the project the majority of respondents say villagers see protected areas as constraints and not as an opportunity especially income generation Alternative activities initiated by the project will have to be intensified in order to have a significant impact on local populations of protected areas Moreover given the countrys instability which strongly impacts tourism and very limited resources lack of cofinancing anticipated investment in ecotourism home can be very risky
The MTR reports
Even though populations have been involved in the project the majority of enquired villagers see PA as constraints and not as an opportunity Alternative activities initiated by the project will have to be intensified to have a significant impact on the populations living near the PA The project team could not provide any socioeconomic study quantifying generated income of the projects beneficiaries Moreover given the countrys instability strongly impacting tourism and the limited resources absence of expected cofunding the MTR warns on the risk inherent in investing in ecotouristic welcoming
Project team has been asked to lead a reflection on it and reconsider this objective if needed
In conclusion the MTR assesses that the objective will not be reached by the end of December 2015 It recommends to revise the initial objective of creating 3 sites of ecotourism to focus on one pilot even 0 according to the results of the reflection led by the project team and reinforce alternative activities with populations living near PA in particular by developing partnerships with the projects of the given zone

description.narrative: 5 Capacity Assessment Scorecard

comment.narrative: see below
see below

broken down by subindicators below herein narrative assessment based on the MTR
The CDS tool permits to measure the increase of the capacities of actors involved in PA management It was applied in 2009 during project formulation It considers the systemic level PA system the institutional level involved entities and the individual level During the MTR MidTerm Review field mission the CDS was applied in order to measure the evolution in terms of capacity development since the project started
The results
Systemic 1230 42
Institutional 1345 34
Individual 921 44
Average 35
The material technical and human capacities granted for PA management are limited and have lightly improved during the project It can surely be explained by the major crisis that Mali had to face institutions have largely been weakened and the State suppressed funds for the PA system in particular the majority of the project cofunding However Mali could have benefited from international skills but the project team did not enlist them
For instance regarding the occupation of the PA capitalization from other West African country could have helped the project team to anticipate and remedy conflicts through mediation A study trip was realized in Senegal but was not enough to find solutions An experience feedback in the Ivory Coast case like in the CORENA project which realized a complete study on occupation of PA could bring solutions on the PA occupation matter
On the field the presence network of forestry agents in Bafing was lightly rehabilitated but not in a sufficient way regarding needs Agents also need motivation and formation to realize their mission Project has effectively realized formation but 60 of the formed agents have been transferred to other situations This cannot allow capitalizing on achievements and continuing them
If material needs are necessary they are not enough The field surveys have brought to light that surveillance is not efficient even if the project brought 18 motorbikes to ease surveillance No infraction was signaled though satellite imagery reveals an upsurge of infractions illegal exploitation forest clearing etc
Financial perpetuation of the NSPA is a major issue and the project team does not have the skills to realized fund seeking which should be the role devoted to the Principal Technical Advisor The financing study of PA does not meet a sufficient quality It is recommended to elaborate a true Business Plan and a pragmatic financial perpetuation strategy by the end of the project
The MTR assesses that the sensitization level of executive officers technicians local and regional decisiontakers communities and other local stakeholders is not sufficient enough for an efficient PA management system in Mali It is indispensable to forecast an important program to reinforce the capacities and also that the next project ERSAP II accepts the idea of benefiting from international expertise to reinforce its own capacities

description.narrative: Widerlandscape conservation in buffer and transition zones of biosphere reserves of SW Mali will reduce key pressures on core PAs and biodiversity
10 Quantifiable status of vegetative cover in the BafingFalémé Biosphere buffer and transition zones BTZ

comment.narrative:
10a No accurate land use map of PA and BTZ available
10b No marked zoning
10c No clear legal status for BTZ of Biosphere Reserves

10a Arial photography and satellite images treated in GIS
NOTE 2014 a better formulation for this subindicator should be andor
10b BTZs clearly marked on ground direct observation
10c Legal status clarified and understood by 50 of village leaders in surrounding villages questionnaires

Target considered achieved
See comment from MTR
The project obtained and analyzed satellite images of 2010 and 2014 of the BafingFaleme area Ecological monitoring implemented by the project has been able to highlight very strong degradations of the vegetal cover in the area throughout the four years see comments on indicator 3
Main pressures on PA and their biodiversity have not been reduced Images of 2012 and 2015 soon available for the project team will refine the analysis
PCAE Plans Communaux dAction Environnementale were realized 11 communes 3 in Kitas circle 3 in Bafoulabés circle and 5 in Kéniébas circle In order to implement these PCAE Communal Councils must be escorted by the project to obtain funds develop partnerships and ensure their implementation
Identification plates have been posed within migration corridors of the BafingFaleme area However sensitization action whats a BTZ for and formation on bushfires particularly havent yet reached sustainable results Populations escorting must be intensified
The fauna and its habitat management Code includes a clarification of BTZ in Mali Nevertheless this law has not been yet approved see Table 4 BTZ of the BafingFaleme areas are thus not created The evaluation recommends to implement a proactive lobbying to accelerate this legal process
Field surveys showed that populations are confused with the PA classification and to get the differences between each one of them Villagers dont acknowledge limits and functions of BTZ
The midterm evaluation team insists again on the importance of conducting sensitization action preservation cannot be made without the populations
Thus the team rates this indicator MS and recommends 1 to realize an efficient lobbying for the fauna and its habitat law and its decrees 2 to realize a real escort of populations including sensitization 3 reduce realization targets of the BTZ of the project these actions will be able to be continued in a future project still it is important that ERSAP focuses and achieves priority activities

Aiming to measure the biodiversity preservation within the BTZ of the southwest of Mali 6 indicators were suggested in the PRODOC 1 Derby Elk 2 Roan Antelope 3 Buffalo 4 Hippo 5 Lion 6 Chimps
This indicator is too complex regarding the reality of the project and references figures are not all specified or are unreliable This particular issue should have been raised during launching workshop
Two inventories were realized within the Wongo Complex 2013 and 2014 and an inventory was realized within the GaléLimakollé
A German research team is in the Kouroufing NP They observed 1 Leopard 14 chimps baboons Caracals Damans Genettes Mongooses Panthers and Warthogs on the first recordings watched
The evaluation team recommends to establish a partnership protocol with the research and to offer assistance to write down the TOR Terms Of Reference of an internship with the objective of counting the population of a flagship species within the Wongo complex This internship should begin in September starting of the academic term Master degree internship

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Nombre d’infrastructures réhabilitées, équipées et fonctionnelles (Cible : 120 infrastructures) 2. Nombre d’équipements informatiques et bureautiques additionnels mis à la disposition des agents de l’Etat (Cible : 200 kit soit 70% des besoins recensés) 3. Nombre de matériel bureautique et stock de papier livrés aux différentes structures de l’Etat (200 kit soit 70% des besoins recensés) 4. Nombre de mallettes de textes usuels mis à la disposition des services d’ordre et de justice (200 mallettes) 5. Nombre d’initiatives entreprises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration (50 QIP financés par le PNUD avec une forte implication de l’administration)

comment.narrative: 1. Zéro (en 2013) infrastructure et installation en bon état (commissariat de police, prisons et Palais de justice et résidence professionnelle) en état de fonctionnement 2. Cinq pour cent (en 2013) des équipements informatiques et de bureau en état de fonctionnement 3. Cinq pour cent (en 2013) du matériel bureautique et stock de papier disponible 4. Zéro (2013) textes du droit positif applicable par les services d’ordre et de justice disponibles 5. Relation de travail et de confiance entre l’administration et les populations détériorées

1. Vingt-deux (22) infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles (Brigade des stupéfiants de Bamako: 1, Tribunaux et logements d’astreinte des juges de Diré (Tombouctou) : 2, de Goundam (Tombouctou): 2, de Gourma Rharous (Tombouctou): 2, de Youwarou (Mopti) : 2, de Douentza (Mopti) : 2, le Tribunal de Mopti: 1, la Cour d’appel de Sévaré (Mopti): 2, de Téninkou : 2, Ansongo: 2, Ménaka: 2 et Bourem: 2) 2. Deux cent cinquante (250) divers équipements informatiques et mobiliers de bureau livrés aux préfectures, sous préfectures, mairies et prisons des régions de Gao (Gao, Ansongo, Bourem, Ménaka); les prison, préfecture et sous préfecture de Kidal; la prison, le commissariat de Mopti (Youwarou, Teninkou, Douentza, Mopti) 3. Cent (100) matériels de bureau et stock de papier livrés aux 5 maisons d’arrêt de Tombouctou, Diré, Goundam, Niafounké, Gourma rharous, au Tribunal de Grande instance de Tombouctou et la Direction régionale de l’administration pénitentiaire de Tombouctou 4. Deux cent (200) mallettes de textes usuels mis à la disposition des services d’ordre et de justice, notamment les maisons d’arrêt de Gao, Mopti et Douentza 5. Quinze (15) initiatives prises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration

1. 14 infrastructures réhabilitées et fonctionnelles dont la brigade des stupéfiants de Bamako:1, Tribunaux et logements d’astreinte des juges de Diré (Tombouctou) : 2, de Goundam (Tombouctou): 2, de Gourma Rharous (Tombouctou): 2, de Youwarou (Mopti) : 2, de Douentza (Mopti) : 2, le Tribunal de Mopti: 1 et la Cour d’appel de Sévaré (Mopti): 2 2.120 divers équipements informatiques et mobiliers de bureau livrés aux prisons de Douentza et de Mopti 3. 200 matériels de bureau et stock de papier livrés aux 5 maisons d’arrêt de Tombouctou, Diré, Goundam, Niafounké, Gourma rharous, au Tribunal de Grande instance de Tombouctou et la Direction régionale de l’administration pénitentiaire de Tombouctou 4. 0 5. 04 initiatives (Transformation des produits maraîchers, la Savonnerie, l'Embouche bovine et la Production de pain locale) prises pour améliorer les relations de travail et restaurer la confiance entre les usagers et l’administration (Tombouctou)

description.narrative: 1. Pourcentage de femmes enceintes qui connaissent leur statut sérologique à l'égard du VIH, 2. Pourcentage de femmes enceintes séropositives au VIH ayant reçu des antirétroviraux dans le but de réduire le risque de transmission de la mère à l'enfant, 3. Pourcentage de nourrissons, nés de femmes infectées par le VIH, ayant bénéficié d'un dépistage du VIH dans les 2 mois qui ont suivi leur naissance, 4. Pourcentage d'adultes et d'enfants bénéficiant actuellement d'un traitement antirétroviral sur l’ensemble des adultes et des enfants vivant avec le VIH, 5. Pourcentage d'établissements de santé dispensant des traitements antirétroviraux qui ont connu une rupture de stock pour au moins l'un des médicaments antirétroviraux requis au cours des 12 derniers mois, 6. Pourcentage des personnes vivant avec le VIH qui reçoivent des soins (y compris ARV), 7. Pourcentage de patients tuberculeux dont un résultat de test VIH a été enregistré dans le registre de la tuberculose, 8. Pourcentage de patients tuberculeux séropositifs au VIH bénéficiant d’une thérapie antirétrovirale pendant le traitement antituberculeux, 9. Pourcentage de patients séropositifs au VIH qui ont fait l'objet d'un dépistage de la tuberculose dans des structures de soins ou de prise en charge du VIH, 10. Pourcentage de nouveaux patients séropositifs au VIH qui ont commencé un traitement préventif par l’isoniazide (TPI) au cours de la période de rapportage, 11. Pourcentage des sites PTME ayant fourni des rapports de données de routine dans les délais, 12. : Pourcentage des sites PTME ayant fourni des rapports sur les données de routine, 13. Pourcentage d'entités du SNIS ou autres entités de rapportage de données de routine présentant leurs rapports dans les délais selon les directives nationales, 14. Pourcentage d'établissements de santé n'ayant pas signalé de rupture de stock de Cotrimoxazole, 15. Nombre de femmes et d'hommes âgés de 15+ ans qui ont fait un test VIH et connaissent les résultats.

comment.narrative: 1. Les conditions de détention actuelles ne sont pas en conformité avec des règles Nelson Mandela des Nations Unies 2. Le taux d’engorgement actuel des centres de détention n’est pas conforme aux standards internationaux en cette matière 3. Les détenus ne bénéficient d’aucun accompagnement pour passer en jugements dans les délais fixés par la loi 4. Le dispositif actuel de réinsertion sociale des prisonniers n’est pas fonctionnel
